dimcat.grouper package¶

Submodules¶

dimcat.grouper.base module¶

A Grouper is a PipelineStep that groups rows of the Data together into subsets.

class dimcat.grouper.base.CorpusGrouper(sort=True)[source]¶

Bases: Grouper

Groups indices that belong to the same corpus.

criterion(index: tuple, dataset: Dataset) → str[source]¶

Takes one index and (potentially) looks it up in the data object to return the name of the new group that the corresponding element is attributed to. The name will be appended to the previous group names tuple.

class dimcat.grouper.base.Grouper(sort=True)[source]¶

Bases: PipelineStep, ABC

A Grouper will process a Data object by iterating through the current index groups and introducing subgroups for each. Groupers always work top-down, meaning that they cannot group IDs belonging to different groups.

Concretely, it will turn the {(old_groups) -> [(id)]} dict stored in data.indices into {(*old_groups, new_group) -> [(id)]}.

abstract criterion(index: tuple, dataset: Dataset) → str[source]¶

Takes one index and (potentially) looks it up in the data object to return the name of the new group that the corresponding element is attributed to. The name will be appended to the previous group names tuple.

filename_factory()[source]¶
level_names¶

“index_level_name”} so that the DataFrame index level distinguishing the resulting groups has a meaningful name. E.g., for grouping by years, a good index level name could be ‘year’.

Type:

Define {“grouper”

process_data(dataset: Dataset) → GroupedData[source]¶

Returns a copy of the Data object where the list of indices for each existing group has been further subdivided into smaller groups.

class dimcat.grouper.base.ModeGrouper(sort=True)[source]¶

Bases: Grouper

Groups indices based on the mode of a given segment. Requires previous application of LocalKeySlicer.
